arguments.claim: The suit lands belong to Sri Janardhana Swami Varu.

anchor.surface_text: The suit lands belong to Sri Janardhana Swami Varu. In 1851, one Ponnuri Anandu, the then Archaka and de facto trustee of the temple, arranged with Nuli Peda Narasimhulu, the great grandfather of the first defendant, that the latter would supply one- Fourth seer of gingili oil every day to the temple and instead of receiving the price of the oil would enjoy the income of the lands.

arguments.claim: The arrangement was reduced into writing but did not amount to an alienation; it gave only a license to receive the income and appropriate it towards the price of the oil.

anchor.surface_text: The arrangement was reduced into writing. The first defendant and his predecessors have been in possession of the lands under this arrangement. The arrangement did number amount to an alienation it gave only a license to receive the income and appropriate it towards the price of the oil.

arguments.claim: Defendants' documents do not displace deity's title; recitals are unilateral admissions.

anchor.surface_text: These unilateral declarations cannot affect the title of the deity. Moreover, these documents companytain admissions that the lands were entered in the village accounts in the name of the deity.

anchor.surface_text: The suit is one by a landlord to recover possession from a tenant and is governed by Art. 139. The tenancy was determined in 1949, and the suit being instituted on November 1, 1954 is well within time.

holdings.text: We are satisfied that the deity is the owner of the lands.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the deity is the owner of the lands. We reject the claim of the defendants that in 1851 either Peda Narasimhulu or Ponnuri Anandu was the owner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public records consistently show deity as inamdar; defendants' documents contain admissions and do not displace title.

holdings.text: We reject the claim of the defendants that by the Sanad dated November 10, 1851, the lands were conveyed to Peda Narasimhulu subject to the burden of supplying oil for evening lighting purposes.

anchor.surface_text: We reject the claim of the defendants that by the Sanad dated November 10, 1,851, the lands were conveyed to Peda Narasimhulu subject to the burden of supplying oil

holdings.reasoning_summary: Village accounts show deity as inamdar; pattas issued to deity, not defendants.

holdings.text: We are satisfied that the legal representatives of Nuli Subba Rao are, still in possession of the Sanad and that they have deliberately withheld it.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the legal representatives of Nuli Subba Rao are, still in possession of the Sanad and that they have deliberately withheld it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Produced other ancient documents; references in their docs show possession until suit.

holdings.text: We hold that the Sanad granted to Peda Narasimhulu a lease of the suit lands from year to year in consideration of his rendering one-fourth seer of gingili oil every day to the temple.

anchor.surface_text: Considering all these facts, we hold that the Sanad granted to Peda Narasimhulu a lease of the suit lands from year to year in consideration of his rendering one-fourth seer of gingili oil every day to the temple.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction of deed; withholding Sanad presumes against permanent; consistent with manager's authority for yearly leases; presumption against permanent for endowments.

holdings.text: The manager of the endowment has no power to grant such a lease [permanent at fixed rent] in the absence of legal necessity.

anchor.surface_text: the manager of the endowment has no power to grant such a lease in the absence of legal necessity, and the Court will not presume a breach of duty on his part.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedents on endowment manager powers.

holdings.text: Having regard to s. 116 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872, during the continuance of the tenancy, a tenant will not be permitted to deny the title of the deity at the beginning of the tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to s. 116 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872, during the continuance of the tenancy, a tenant will not be permitted to deny the title of the deity at the beginning of the tenancy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tenant estoppel applies; possession not adverse during tenancy.

holdings.text: It is also well settled that during the continuance of the tenancy, the tenant cannot acquire by prescription a permanent right of occupancy in derogation of the landlords title by mere assertion of such a right.

anchor.surface_text: It is also well settled that during the continuance of the tenancy, the tenant cannot acquire by prescription a permanent right of occupancy in derogation of the landlords title by mere assertion of such a right

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents confirm no prescription during tenancy.

holdings.text: During the period from 1851 to 1929 the title of the deity was not extinguished by adverse possession under S. 28 read with Art. 144 of the Indian Limitation Act, 1908.

anchor.surface_text: During the period from 1851 to 1929 the title of the deity was not extinguished by adverse possession under S. 28 read with Art. 144 of the Indian Limitation Act, 1908

holdings.reasoning_summary: No adverse possession due to tenancy estoppel.

holdings.text: Nor was the title of the deity extinguished [from 1929 to 1949] by the operation of s. 28 read with Art. 134-B [Limitation Act 1908].

anchor.surface_text: Nor was the title of the deity extinguished the period from 1929 to 1949 by the operation of s. 28 read with Art. 134-B introduced in the Indian Limitation Act. 1908

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.134B applies to illegal transfers by ex-managers, not lawful yearly leases continuing post-tenure.

holdings.text: The suit is one by a landlord to recover possession from a tenant and is governed by Art. 139.

anchor.surface_text: The suit is one by a landlord to recover possession from a tenant and is governed by Art. 139.

holdings.text: The tenancy was determined in 1949, and the suit being instituted on November 1, 1954 is well within time.

anchor.surface_text: The tenancy was determined in 1949, and the suit being instituted on November 1, 1954 is well within time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Within 3 years under Art.139 from termination notice.

holdings.text: The contention that Peda Narasimhulu and his successors-in-interest acquired title to the suit lands by prescription and the suit is barred by limitation is therefore, rejected.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: no adverse possession, correct limitation article.

holdings.text: The plaintiff is, therefore, entitled to recover the suit lands.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff is, therefore, entitled to recover the suit lands. In the result, the appeal is allowed,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deity owner; terminable yearly tenancy ended; suit in time.

precedents.case_name: Bastacolla Colliery Co Ltd v Bandhu Beldar
precedents.cited_proposition: lessee may acquire permanent right by prescription if pays rent on basis of notorious claim to knowledge of owner
precedents.cited_holding: There are however, some cases in which a lessee can acquire the right of a permanent right by prescription in spite of payment and acceptance of rent. Those are cases where the lessee pays rent on the basis of a notorious claim of permanent tenancy to the knowledge of the owner.
